template.template: Template OS Linux by Zabbix agent active
template.name: Template OS Linux by Zabbix agent active
template.description:
Name: Template OS Linux by Zabbix agent active
Description: Aggregate templates for monitoring Linux components
Homepage: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix
Issues: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix/issues
Author: itmicus.ru
Version: 1.0
Changelog: The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/)
## [1.0.0] - 2019-09-03 ### Added - Separation of operating system monitoring into major components: cpu, memory, disk, network - Templates follow Zabbix template guidelines (https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/4.4/manual/appendix/templates/template_guidelines) - All triggers redesigned, only key triggers left that show real problems - All macros and regular expressions moved to templates

template.name: Template OS Linux CPU by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Linux Inventory by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Linux Memory by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Linux Network by Zabbix agent active

template.template: Template OS Linux CPU by Zabbix agent active
template.name: Template OS Linux CPU by Zabbix agent active
template.description:
Name: Template OS Linux CPU by Zabbix agent active
Description:Template for monitoring Linux CPU
Homepage: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix
Issues: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix/issues
Author: itmicus.ru
Version: 1.0
Changelog: The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/)
## [1.0.0] - 2019-09-03 ### Added - Templates follow Zabbix template guidelines (https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/4.4/manual/appendix/templates/template_guidelines)

item.name: CPU: Load (1 min average per core)
item.description: The processor load is calculated as system CPU load divided by number of CPU cores.

item.name: CPU: Load (5 min average per core)
item.description: The processor load is calculated as system CPU load divided by number of CPU cores.

item.name: CPU: Load (15 min average per core)
item.description: The processor load is calculated as system CPU load divided by number of CPU cores.

item.name: CPU: Idle time
item.description: The time the CPU has spent doing nothing.

item.name: CPU: Interrupt time
item.description: The amount of time the CPU has been servicing hardware interrupts.

item.name: CPU: Iowait time
item.description: Amount of time the CPU has been waiting for I/O to complete.

item.name: CPU: Nice time
item.description: The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that have been niced.

item.name: CPU: Softirq time
item.description: The amount of time the CPU has been servicing software interrupts.

item.name: CPU: Steal time
item.description: The amount of CPU 'stolen' from this virtual machine by the hypervisor for other tasks (such as running another virtual machine).

item.name: CPU: System time
item.description: The time the CPU has spent running the kernel and its processes.

item.name: CPU: User time
item.description: The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that are not niced.

template.template: Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active
template.name: Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active
template.description:
Name: Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active
Description: Template for monitoring Linux Disk and softare RAID
Homepage: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix
Issues: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix/issues
Author: itmicus.ru
Version: 1.0
Changelog: The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/)
## [1.0.0] - 2019-09-03 ### Added - Templates follow Zabbix template guidelines (https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/4.4/manual/appendix/templates/template_guidelines)
For explanation:
Monitoring of MD Soft RAID: https://github.com/krom/zabbix_template_md and https://github.com/q1x/zabbix-templates/tree/master/linux-md
disks (kernel 2.6+): wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/krom/zabbix_template_md/master/userparameter_md.conf https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/iostats.txt
Количество операций в секунду (ops) Пропускная способность (throughput) Время обработки запроса (latency или правильней svctime) Утилизация дисковой подсистемы (utilization)

item_prototype.name: {#MDNAME}: degraded
item_prototype.description: Get number of degraded disks

item_prototype.name: {#MDNAME}: raid disks
item_prototype.description: Get number of all disks

item_prototype.name: {#MDNAME}: sync action
item_prototype.description: Get current sync action

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active:md.sync_action[{#MDNAME}].str(recover)}=1
trigger_prototype.name: {#MDNAME}: MD in recovery mode

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active:md.degraded[{#MDNAME}].last()}>0
trigger_prototype.name: {#MDNAME}: MD is degraded

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active:md.raid_disks[{#MDNAME}].diff()}>0
trigger_prototype.name: {#MDNAME}: number of disks changed

item.host: Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active

discovery_rule.name: Mounted filesystem discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of file systems of different types as defined in global regular expression "File systems for discovery".

item_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Free inodes percent for 12h linear forecast shifted
{#FSNAME}: Used disk space for 12h linear forecast shifted
{#FSNAME}: Used disk space for 12h linear forecast

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active:vfs.fs.inode.forecast12hshifted[{#FSNAME}].last(0)}<{$DISK.INODE.MIN.PCT:"{#FSNAME}"}
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active:vfs.fs.inode.forecast12hshifted[{#FSNAME}].last(0)}>({$DISK.INODE.MIN.PCT:"{#FSNAME}"}+3)
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: FORECAST Free inodes is less than {$DISK.INODE.MIN.PCT:"{#FSNAME}"}%

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},free].last(0)}<{$DISK.FILESYSTEM.SPACE.LIMIT:"{#FSNAME}"}
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},free].last(0)}>{$DISK.FILESYSTEM.SPACE.LIMIT:"{#FSNAME}"}
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Free disk space is less than {$DISK.FILESYSTEM.SPACE.LIMIT:"{#FSNAME}"}

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active:vfs.fs.inode[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}<{$DISK.INODE.MIN.PCT:"{#FSNAME}"}
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active:vfs.fs.inode[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}>({$DISK.INODE.MIN.PCT:"{#FSNAME}"}+3)
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Free inodes is less than {$DISK.INODE.MIN.PCT:"{#FSNAME}"}

item.host: Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Linux Disk by Zabbix agent active

template.name: Template OS Linux Disk Performance by Zabbix agent active

template.template: Template OS Linux Disk Performance by Zabbix agent active
template.name: Template OS Linux Disk Performance by Zabbix agent active
template.description:
Name: Template OS Linux Disk Performance by Zabbix agent active
Description:Template for monitoring Linux Disk Performance
Homepage: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix
Issues: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix/issues
Author: itmicus.ru
Version: 1.0
Changelog: The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/)
## [1.0.0] - 2019-09-03 ### Added - Templates follow Zabbix template guidelines (https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/4.4/manual/appendix/templates/template_guidelines)
For explanation: 1. https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/iostats.txt 2. https://habr.com/ru/post/377757/ 3. https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/block/stat.txt 4. https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/55212/how-can-i-monitor-disk-io

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Discards merged
item_prototype.description: Field 13 -- # of discards merged See the description of field 2

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Discards ms
item_prototype.description: Field 10 -- # of milliseconds spent doing I/Os This field increases so long as field 9 is nonzero.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Discards Ops per second
item_prototype.description: Field 12 -- # of discards completed This is the total number of discards completed successfully.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: IO Currently Active
item_prototype.description: Field 9 -- # of I/Os currently in progress The only field that should go to zero. Incremented as requests are given to appropriate struct request_queue and decremented as they finish.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Util
item_prototype.description: Field 10 -- # of milliseconds spent doing I/Os This field increases so long as field 9 is nonzero.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Read Merged
item_prototype.description: Field 2 -- # of reads merged, field 6 -- # of writes merged Reads and writes which are adjacent to each other may be merged for efficiency. Thus two 4K reads may become one 8K read before it is ultimately handed to the disk, and so it will be counted (and queued) as only one I/O. This field lets you know how often this was done.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Read ms
item_prototype.description: Field #7 Number of milliseconds spent reading This is the total number of milliseconds spent by all reads (as measured from __make_request() to end_that_request_last()).

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Read Ops per second
item_prototype.description: Field 1 -- # of reads completed This is the total number of reads completed successfully.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Read Bytes/sec
item_prototype.description: Field 4 -- # of milliseconds spent reading This is the total number of milliseconds spent by all reads (as measured from __make_request() to end_that_request_last()).

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: IO Weight ms
item_prototype.description: Field 11 -- weighted # of milliseconds spent doing I/Os This field is incremented at each I/O start, I/O completion, I/O merge, or read of these stats by the number of I/Os in progress (field 9) times the number of milliseconds spent doing I/O since the last update of this field. This can provide an easy measure of both I/O completion time and the backlog that may be accumulating.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Write Merged
item_prototype.description: Field 6 -- # of writes merged See the description of field 2.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Write ms
item_prototype.description: Field 8 -- # of milliseconds spent writing This is the total number of milliseconds spent by all writes (as measured from __make_request() to end_that_request_last()).

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Write Ops per second
item_prototype.description: Field 5 -- # of writes completed This is the total number of writes completed successfully.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Write Bytes/sec
item_prototype.description: Field #10 This is the total number of sectors written successfully.

template.template: Template OS Linux Inventory by Zabbix agent active
template.name: Template OS Linux Inventory by Zabbix agent active
template.description:
Name: Template OS Linux Inventory by Zabbix agent active
Description: Template for collect inventory on Linux
Homepage: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix
Issues: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix/issues
Author: itmicus.ru
Version: 1.0
Changelog: The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/)
## [1.0.0] - 2019-09-03 ### Added - Templates follow Zabbix template guidelines (https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/4.4/manual/appendix/templates/template_guidelines)

item.name: OS: number of running processes
item.description: Number of processes in running state.

item.name: OS: number of processes
item.description: Total number of processes in any state.

item.name: OS: hostname
item.description: System host name.

item.name: OS: information
item.description: The information as normally returned by 'uname -a'.

item.name: OS: number of logged in users
item.description: Number of users who are currently logged in.

template.template: Template OS Linux Memory by Zabbix agent active
template.name: Template OS Linux Memory by Zabbix agent active
template.description:
Name: Template OS Linux Memory by Zabbix agent active
Description: Template for monitoring Linux Memory
Homepage: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix
Issues: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix/issues
Author: itmicus.ru
Version: 1.0
Changelog: The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/)
## [1.0.0] - 2019-09-03 ### Added - Separation of operating system monitoring into major components: cpu, memory, disk, network - Templates follow Zabbix template guidelines (https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/4.4/manual/appendix/templates/template_guidelines) - All triggers redesigned, only key triggers left that show real problems - All macros and regular expressions moved to templates

item.name: Meminfo: Active
item.description: Memory that has been used more recently and usually not swapped out or reclaimed.

item.name: Meminfo: Anon Huge Pages
item.description: The total amount of memory, in kibibytes, used by huge pages that are not backed by files and are mapped into userspace page tables.

item.name: Meminfo: Anon Pages
item.description: The total amount of memory, in kibibytes, used by pages that are not backed by files and are mapped into userspace page tables.

item.name: Meminfo: Buffers
item.description: Memory in buffer cache, so relatively temporary storage for raw disk blocks. This shouldn't get very large.

item.name: Meminfo: Cached
item.description: Memory in the pagecache (Diskcache and Shared Memory)

item.name: Meminfo: Commited AS
item.description: The total amount of memory, in kibibytes, estimated to complete the workload. This value represents the worst case scenario value, and also includes swap memory.

item.name: Meminfo: Commit Limit
item.description: The total amount of memory currently available to be allocated on the system based on the overcommit ratio (vm.overcommit_ratio). This limit is only adhered to if strict overcommit accounting is enabled (mode 2 in vm.overcommit_memory).

item.name: Meminfo: Dirty
item.description: Memory waiting to be written back to disk.

item.name: Meminfo: Get data
item.description: cat /proc/meminfo text

item.name: Meminfo: Hardware Corrupted
item.description: The amount of RAM the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

item.name: Meminfo: Huge Pages Free
item.description: The total number of hugepages available for the system. This statistic only appears on the x86, Itanium, and AMD64 architectures.

item.name: Meminfo: Huge Pages Rsvd
item.description: The number of hugepages for which a commitment to allocate from the pool has been made, but no allocation has yet been made.

item.name: Meminfo: Huge Pages Surp
item.description: The number of surplus huge pages.

item.name: Meminfo: Huge Pages Total
item.description: Number of hugepages being allocated by the kernel (Defined with vm.nr_hugepages)

item.name: Meminfo: Inactive
item.description: Memory that has not been used recently and can be swapped out or reclaimed.

item.name: Meminfo: Memory Available
item.description: An estimate of how much memory is available for starting new applications, without swapping.

item.name: Meminfo: Memory Free
item.description: The amount of physical memory not used by the system

item.name: Meminfo: Memory Total
item.description: Total usable memory

item.name: Meminfo: Mlocked
item.description: Pages locked to memory using the mlock() system call. Mlocked pages are also Unevictable.

item.name: Meminfo: Shared Memory
item.description: The total amount of memory, in kibibytes, used by shared memory (shmem) and tmpfs.

item.name: Meminfo: Slab
item.description: The total amount of memory, in kibibytes, used by the kernel to cache data structures for its own use.

item.name: Meminfo: Slab Reclaimable
item.description: The part of Slab that can be reclaimed, such as caches.

item.name: Meminfo: Slab Unreclaim
item.description: The part of Slab that cannot be reclaimed even when lacking memory.

item.name: Meminfo: Swap Cached
item.description: Memory that is present within main memory, but also in the swapfile. (If memory is needed this area does not need to be swapped out AGAIN because it is already in the swapfile. This saves I/O and increases performance if machine runs short on memory.)

item.name: Meminfo: Swap Free
item.description: The remaining swap space available.

item.name: Meminfo: Swap Total
item.description: Total swap space available.

item.name: Meminfo: Swap Used
item.description: Swap Used (calculated)

item.name: Meminfo: Swap Used w/o cached
item.description: Swap Used without Cached (calculated)

item.name: Meminfo: Unevictable
item.description: Unevictable pages can't be swapped out for a variety of reasons.

item.name: Meminfo: Writeback
item.description: Memory which is actively being written back to disk.

item.name: Swap: Swap In pages/sec
item.description: Swap in (from device into memory) statistics.

item.name: Swap: Swap Out pages/sec
item.description: Swap out (from memory onto device) statistics.

item.name: Memory: Available memory
item.description: Available memory is defined as free+cached+buffers memory.

item.name: Memory: Occupied
item.description: Occupied memory: total - available;

template.template: Template OS Linux Network by Zabbix agent active
template.name: Template OS Linux Network by Zabbix agent active
template.description:
Name: Template OS Linux Network by Zabbix agent active
Description: Template for monitoring Linux Network
Homepage: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix
Issues: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix/issues
Author: itmicus.ru
Version: 1.0
Changelog: The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/)
## [1.0.0] - 2019-09-03 ### Added - Separation of operating system monitoring into major components: cpu, memory, disk, network - Templates follow Zabbix template guidelines (https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/4.4/manual/appendix/templates/template_guidelines) - All triggers redesigned, only key triggers left that show real problems - All macros and regular expressions moved to templates
### Changed
For explanation:
network: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/sysfs-class-net
# if ethtool installed UserParameter=custom.netif.ethtool[*],ethtool $1 2>/dev/null || echo "N/A" #https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/sysfs-class-net UserParameter=custom.netif.speed[*],cat /sys/class/net/$1/speed 2>/dev/null || echo 0 UserParameter=custom.netif.carrier[*],cat /sys/class/net/$1/carrier 2>/dev/null || echo 0 UserParameter=custom.netif.operstate[*],cat /sys/class/net/$1/operstate 2>/dev/null || echo -1 UserParameter=custom.netif.name_assign_type[*],cat /sys/class/net/$1/name_assign_type 2>/dev/null || echo 0 UserParameter=custom.netif.addr_assign_type[*],cat /sys/class/net/$1/addr_assign_type 2>/dev/null || echo 0 UserParameter=custom.netif.address[*],cat /sys/class/net/$1/address 2>/dev/null || echo "N/A" UserParameter=custom.netif.dev_id[*],cat /sys/class/net/$1/dev_id 2>/dev/null || echo "N/A" UserParameter=custom.netif.duplex[*],cat /sys/class/net/$1/duplex 2>/dev/null || echo "N/A" UserParameter=custom.netif.type[*],cat /sys/class/net/$1/type 2>/dev/null || echo -1
#Apache UserParameter=zapache[*],/etc/zabbix_itmicus/scripts/zapache \$1 memory based on https://access.redhat.com/solutions/406773
UserParameter=ip_conntrack_count,cat /proc/sys/net/ipv4/netfilter/ip_conntrack_count UserParameter=ip_conntrack_max,cat /proc/sys/net/ipv4/netfilter/ip_conntrack_max
Monitoring of MD Soft RAID: https://github.com/krom/zabbix_template_md and https://github.com/q1x/zabbix-templates/tree/master/linux-md
disks (kernel 2.6+): wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/krom/zabbix_template_md/master/userparameter_md.conf https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/iostats.txt
Количество операций в секунду (ops) Пропускная способность (throughput) Время обработки запроса (latency или правильней svctime) Утилизация дисковой подсистемы (utilization)
CPU: https://habr.com/ru/post/216827/

discovery_rule.name: Network interface discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of network interfaces as defined in global regular expression "Network interfaces for discovery".

item_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Network address
item_prototype.description: KernelVersion: 2.6.12 Hardware address currently assigned to this interface. Format is a string, e.g: 00:11:22:33:44:55 for an Ethernet MAC address.

item_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Network addr_assign_type
item_prototype.description: KernelVersion: 3.2 Indicates the address assignment type. Possible values are: 0: permanent address 1: randomly generated 2: stolen from another device 3: set using dev_set_mac_address

item_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Network carrier
item_prototype.description: KernelVersion: 2.6.12 Indicates the current physical link state of the interface. Posssible values are: 0: physical link is down 1: physical link is up Note: some special devices, e.g: bonding and team drivers will allow this attribute to be written to force a link state for operating correctly and designating another fallback interface.

item_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Network dev_id
item_prototype.description: KernelVersion: 2.6.26 Indicates the device unique identifier. Format is an hexadecimal value. This is used to disambiguate interfaces which might be stacked (e.g: VLAN interfaces) but still have the same MAC address as their parent device.

item_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Network duplex
item_prototype.description: KernelVersion: 2.6.33 Indicates the interface latest or current duplex value. Possible values are: half: half duplex full: full duplex Note: This attribute is only valid for interfaces that implement the ethtool get_settings method (mostly Ethernet).

item_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Network name_assign_type
item_prototype.description: KernelVersion: 3.17 Indicates the name assignment type. Possible values are: 1: enumerated by the kernel, possibly in an unpredictable way 2: predictably named by the kernel 3: named by userspace 4: renamed

item_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Network operstate
item_prototype.description: KernelVersion: 2.6.17 Indicates the interface RFC2863 operational state as a string. Possible values are: "unknown", "notpresent", "down", "lowerlayerdown", "testing", "dormant", "up".

item_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Network speed
item_prototype.description: KernelVersion: 2.6.33 Indicates the interface latest or current speed value. Value is an integer representing the link speed in Mbits/sec. Note: this attribute is only valid for interfaces that implement the ethtool get_settings method (mostly Ethernet ).

item_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Network type
item_prototype.description: KernelVersion: 2.6.12 Indicates the interface protocol type as a decimal value. See include/uapi/linux/if_arp.h for all possible values.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Network by Zabbix agent active:custom.netif.carrier[{#IFNAME}].diff(0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Changed network carrier on

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Network by Zabbix agent active:custom.netif.duplex[{#IFNAME}].diff(0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Changed network duplex

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Network by Zabbix agent active:custom.netif.operstate[{#IFNAME}].diff(0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Changed network operation state

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Network by Zabbix agent active:custom.netif.speed[{#IFNAME}].diff(0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Changed network speed

item.host: Template OS Linux Network by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Linux Network by Zabbix agent active

trigger.expression: {Template OS Linux CPU by Zabbix agent active:system.cpu.load[percpu,avg1].avg(30m)}>{$CPU.LOAD.MAX.PCT}
trigger.name: CPU: Load is too high (over {$CPU.LOAD.MAX.PCT}% for 30m)

trigger.expression: {Template OS Linux CPU by Zabbix agent active:system.cpu.util[,iowait].avg(30m)}>{$CPU.IOWAIT.MAX}
trigger.recovery_expression: {Template OS Linux CPU by Zabbix agent active:system.cpu.util[,iowait].avg(1h)}<{$CPU.IOWAIT.MAX}
trigger.name: CPU: Waiting I/O (over {$CPU.IOWAIT.MAX} for 30m)
trigger.description: OS spends significant time waiting for I/O (input/output) operations. It could be indicator of performance issues with storage system.

trigger.expression: {Template OS Linux Memory by Zabbix agent active:vm.memory.size[available].last(0)}<{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN}
trigger.recovery_expression: {Template OS Linux Memory by Zabbix agent active:vm.memory.size[available].last(0)}>{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN}
trigger.name: Memory: Lack of available memory

trigger.expression: {Template OS Linux Memory by Zabbix agent active:custom.meminfo.hardwarecorrupted.last()}>1
trigger.name: Memory: Meminfo found Hardware Corrupted memory
trigger.description: HardwareCorrupted show the amount of memory in "poisoned pages", i.e. memory which has failed (as flagged by ECC typically). ECC stands for "Error Correcting Code". ECC memory is capable of correcting small errors and detecting larger ones; on typical PCs with non-ECC memory, memory errors go undetected. If an uncorrectable error is detected using ECC (in memory or cache, depending on the system's hardware support), then the Linux kernel marks the corresponding page as poisoned.

trigger.expression: {Template OS Linux Memory by Zabbix agent active:custom.meminfo.commitedas.last()}>{Template OS Linux Memory by Zabbix agent active:custom.meminfo.commitlimit.last()}*({$MEMORY.OVERCOMMITED.RATIO}/100)
trigger.name: Memory: Overcommited memory (over {$MEMORY.OVERCOMMITED.RATIO}%)
trigger.description:
Please check graph - Memory Overcommit
Debug: 1. Open top 2. Check rss и vss column 3. Get process wich using much memory

trigger.expression: {Template OS Linux Inventory by Zabbix agent active:vfs.file.cksum[/etc/passwd].diff(0)}>0
trigger.name: OS: /etc/passwd has been changed

trigger.expression: {Template OS Linux Inventory by Zabbix agent active:system.uname.diff(0)}>0
trigger.name: OS: Host information was changed

trigger.expression: {Template OS Linux Inventory by Zabbix agent active:system.hostname.diff(0)}>0
trigger.name: OS: Hostname was changed

trigger.expression: {Template OS Linux Inventory by Zabbix agent active:system.localtime[utc].fuzzytime( {$OS.FUZZY.TIME.MAX})}=0
trigger.name: OS: It is necessary to adjust the local time (over {$OS.FUZZY.TIME.MAX} s)

trigger.expression: {Template OS Linux Inventory by Zabbix agent active:system.uptime.change(0)}<0
trigger.name: OS: {HOST.NAME} has just been restarted

item.host: Template OS Linux CPU by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Linux CPU by Zabbix agent active
